Award.AwardTitle: The Highest Redshift Quasars and the Epoch of Reionization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The awardees will carry out a wide-field, medium deep multicolor survey, using the newly commissioned red-optimized CCD camera on the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT) with enhanced sensitivity at 1 micron. This survey will for the first time enable discovery of faint quasars at redshifts z > 7. They will combine the LBT sample with other high luminosity quasars at 6 < z < 8, and will carry out spectroscopic follow-up observations in far red and near-infrared wavelengths. The main science goals of this work are to constrain the accretion history of the earliest supermassive black holes in the Universe, and to determine whether the intergalactic medium becomes largely neutral by z ~6.5 - 8.

Broader impacts of this work include research training for graduate and undergraduate students, follow-up studies of newly discovered quasars, and serendipitous discovery of other types of objects such as brown dwarfs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When did the first luminous objects appear in the Universe? How did the first generations of galaxies and quasars heat up the intergalactic gas, re-ionize the Universe and end the cosmic dark ages? These are among the most important and pressing questions of modern astrophysics and cosmoloyg. This NSF project aimed at making significant progress in answering these questions,  by studying the most distant quasars and galaxies in the Universe. In particular, we utilized three transformational facilities to carry ambitious survey of the distant universe: the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) allowed discovery of the most distant quasars with its wide-field sky coverage; the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT)'s powerful camera and spectrographs enabled detailed studies of faint galaxies and quasars at the edge of the Universe; and the Atacama Large Millimeter/Submillimeter Array (ALMA) opened a new window to study dust emission and star formation in the early universe. With the help of these three facilities, combined with observations from the Hubble and Spitzer space telescopes. our systematic studies of the reionizaion era galaxies and quasars allowed us to:

(1) more than double to the total number of quasars known at z>=6, about one billion years after the big bang, at the end of the cosmic reiionization (SDSS);


(2) map the evolution of distant quasars and the history of growth of the early supermassive black holes at the center of distant galaxies (LBT, HST);


(3) study the physical state of the intergalactic gas and the signature of cosmic reionization which ended the cosmic dark ages (LBT, SDSS);


(4) probe the co-evolution of galaxies and supermassive black holes, and the star formation activities in quasar host galaxies in early universe (ALMA, LBT);


(5) unveil a new type of "dustless" quasars which could be the youngest quasars powered by black holes formed very recently with early, immature structures (SDSS, Spitzer);


(6) and discoverya new population of ultra-luminous star forming galaxies at the peak era of cosmic star formation, likely the link of normal star forming galaxies and the most intense galaxy merger (LBT, HST).

Supported by this grant we have palso articipated in a wide range of educational and outreach activities that have board impact. Research described here involves five graduate students (four completed and on-going Ph.D. theses), four postdoc fellows and four undergraduate students in our group; among them four are women. Two undergraduate students are now in astronomy/physics Ph.D. programs,  two recently-graduated Ph.D. students received prestigious postdoc fellowships, and two postdocs are now entering tenure-track faculty positions. Our outreach activities utilized our strong connection to the LBT:  a summer high school enrichment program in rural Arizona, strong majority of which were Native American and Hispanic; TV interviews and documentaries by BBC, National Geographic and for the International Year of Astronomy; and a wide range of public lectures. In all outreach activities, high-redshift quasar survey directly supported by this grant was highlighted. Our research have also been featured in a number of press releases and press conferences by NASA, Nature, NRAO, AAS and IAU.
